User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user profile in the application.

id.description: Unique identifier for the user entity.

name.description: The full name of the user.

email.description: The email address of the user.

role.description: The role of the user in the application (e.g., HEAD_SALES, SALES).

group.description: The sales group the user belongs to (e.g., Yogyakarta, Pekanbaru).

createdAt.description: The timestamp when the user account was created.

Chat.title: Chat
Chat.description: Represents a conversation between two or more users.

participants.description: An array of user UIDs who are part of the chat.

lastMessageText.description: The text of the last message sent in the chat.

lastMessageTimestamp.description: The timestamp of the last message.

participantNames.description: A map of participant UIDs to their names for easy display.

Message.title: Message
Message.description: Represents a single message within a chat.

senderId.description: The UID of the user who sent the message.

timestamp.description: The timestamp when the message was sent.

definition.description: Stores user profiles, including name, email, role, and creation timestamp. The 'role' field is denormalized to enable Authorization Independence in security rules.

params.name: userId
params.description: The unique identifier for the user, corresponding to the Firebase Auth UID.

definition.description: Stores metadata for each chat conversation.

params.name: chatId
params.description: A unique ID for the chat, typically a combination of participant UIDs.

definition.description: Stores all messages for a specific chat, ordered by timestamp.

params.name: chatId
params.description: The ID of the parent chat.

params.name: messageId
params.description: The unique ID for the message.

firestore.reasoning: The Firestore structure is designed to ensure secure and efficient data access based on user roles (SALES and HEAD_SALES). The core principle is Authorization Independence, achieved by storing the `role` directly within the `users/{uid}` document. This avoids the need for `get()` calls in security rules to fetch the user's role, making operations atomic and easier to debug. The structure also addresses the need for role-based filtering of user data, where a HEAD_SALES user needs to read all users, but a SALES user can only read their own document. Since a path-based approach is adopted, only one collection is used. This approach leverages the DBAC (Database-based Access Control) principle, where roles are stored in the database itself rather than using custom claims.
